sentences.sentence: She soon learnt that his decision to leave Derbyshire in search of her sister had been made before he left the inn,
and that his gravity and thoughtfulness were because his mind was already planning how best to carry out the search.
She thanked him again, but it was too painful a subject for both of them to be discussed any further.
After walking several miles at a slow pace, and barely( 几乎没有 ) noticing that they had done so, they at last found that it was time for them to return home.
“What happened to Mr. Bingley and Jane?” they wondered.
Darcy was very pleased that his friend was now engaged( 订婚 ) to Jane.
Bingley had told him about it before anyone else.
“I have to ask if you were surprised.” said Elizabeth.
“Not at all.
When I last saw them together, I felt that it would soon happen.”
“That is to say, you had given him your permission.
I guessed as much.”
And though he denied( 否认 ) he had done so, she found that it was pretty much what had happened.
“On the evening before I went to London,” he said,
“I made a confession( 坦白 ) to him, which I should have made long ago.
I told him all that had happened since to make my interference( 干涉 ) in his affairs absurd( 荒谬的 ) and impertinent( 鲁莽的 ).
He was greatly surprised and also angry—he had never had the slightest suspicion( 疑心 ).
But his anger ended as soon as I told him that I now believed I had been mistaken in thinking that your sister did not have feelings( 感受 ) for him.
I could easily see that his affection( 喜爱 ) for her had not diminished( 消退 ), and so I felt no doubt that they would soon find happiness together.”
Elizabeth strongly desired to point out that Mr. Bingley had been a wonderful friend, and that it was a valuable trait( 特质 ) for a friend to be guided so easily.
But she stopped herself.
She remembered that Darcy had not yet learned to be laughed at( 被嘲笑 ), and it was rather too early to begin.
Darcy continued the conversation, predicting( 预言 ) Bingley’s happiness and how it would be inferior( 不如 ) only to his own, until they reached the house.
“My dear Lizzy, where have you been walking to?”
Jane asked Elizabeth as soon as she saw her, and everybody else asked the same question again when she sat down at the table.
She could only reply that they had wandered around, until she did not know quite where she was.
She turned red as she spoke, but none of the others had any suspicion( 怀疑 ) about what had really happened.
The evening passed quietly, without anything extraordinary occurring.
The acknowledged( 公开的 ) lovers talked and laughed, while the unacknowledged( 未公开的 ) were silent.
Elizabeth, feeling agitated( 焦虑的 ) and confused( 疑惑的 ), knew that she was happy but did not yet feel it.
Besides feeling presently somewhat embarrassed( 尴尬的 ), she was worried about what would happen next.
She wondered about how the family would react when they found out about her situation, because she knew that no one liked Darcy except Jane.
That night she admitted the truth to Jane.
Though Miss Bennet very seldom suspected( 怀疑 ) that others were lying to her, she at first did not believe it could be true.
“You are joking, Lizzy. This cannot be!—engaged( 订婚 ) to Mr. Darcy! No, no, you will not trick me.
I know it is impossible.”
“This is a miserable( 糟糕的 ) beginning indeed! You were my only hope.
I am sure nobody else will believe me, if you do not.
Yet, indeed, I speak nothing but the truth.
He still loves me, and we are engaged( 订婚的 ).”
Jane looked at her with doubt.
“Oh, Lizzy! It cannot be.
I know how much you dislike him.”
“You know nothing about it.
You must forget everything that you know.
Perhaps I did not always love him as much as I do now.
But in such situations as these, a good memory( 回忆 ) is unpardonable.
In fact, this is the last time I will ever remember how I once felt myself.”
Miss Bennet still looked amazed( 惊讶的 ).
Elizabeth again, and more seriously, promised her that it was true.
“Good Heavens! Can it really be true! Yet now I must really believe you,” cried Jane.
“My dear, dear Lizzy, I would—I do congratulate you—but are you certain?
Please forgive me for asking, but are you quite certain that you can be happy with him?”
“I have absolutely( 完全地 ) no doubt about that.
We are both already certain that we will be the happiest couple in the world.
But are you happy, Jane? Will you be happy to have such a brother-in-law?”
“Very, very much.
Nothing could make either Bingley or myself happier.
Though we had talked about it, we decided that it was impossible.
And do you really love him quite well enough? Lizzy, are you quite sure that you love him?”
“Oh, yes! You will only think that I feel too strongly for him, when I tell you everything.”
“What do you mean?”
“Well, I must confess( 坦白 ) that I love him more than I love Bingley.
I am afraid you will be angry.”
“My dearest sister, please be serious.
I want to talk very seriously.
Let me know everything that I need to know, without delay.
Will you tell me how long you have loved him?”
“It has happened so gradually( 渐渐地 ), that I hardly know when it began.
But I believe it must have started from when I first saw his magnificent( 华丽的 ) home at Pemberley.”
Jane asked her to give her a serious answer, however, which Elizabeth then did.
“Now I am quite happy,” said Jane, “for you will be as happy as I am.
I always liked him. But Lizzy, you have been very secretive( 守口如瓶的 ) with me.
Why did you not tell me what happened at Pemberley and in Lambton? I heard all that I know from Bingley, not from you.”
Elizabeth told the reasons she had kept it a secret.
She had been unwilling to mention Bingley, and since she was not sure about her own feelings( 感受 ), she had also avoided mentioning his friend.
But now she would no longer keep secret from Jane what Darcy had done to help Lydia’s marriage.
She admitted everything, and they spent half the night in conversation.
The next morning, when Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy came again, Mrs. Bennet advised Elizabeth to take another walk with Darcy so that he would not disturb( 打扰 ) their time with Bingley.
During the long walk, it was decided that Darcy would ask for Mr. Bennet’s consent( 同意 ) to their engagement( 订婚 ) during that evening.
Elizabeth herself would ask for her mother’s consent( 同意 ).
In the evening, soon after Mr. Bennet went to the library after having his tea, Elizabeth saw Mr. Darcy stand up also and follow him.
She felt extremely nervous when she saw him do so.
She was not afraid that her father would refuse him, but he was still going to be made unhappy.
She felt terrible that she, his favorite child, would now be causing him distress( 使痛苦 ) about her choice.
She sat there feeling miserable( 糟糕的 ) until Mr. Darcy appeared again.
Looking at him, she was a little relieved by his smile.
In a few minutes he approached the table where she was sitting with Kitty.
While pretending to be curious about what she was doing, he said to her in a whisper, “Go to your father, he wants you in the library.” She went directly.
Her father was walking around the room, looking serious and anxious.
“Lizzy,” said he, “what are you doing? Are you out of your mind, to be accepting this man? Have you not always hated him?”
How greatly she then wished that she had been more reasonable before, or at least not expressed herself so openly!
It would have prevented her from now having to make such awkward( 尴尬的 ) explanations.
But these explanations were now necessary, and she promised him, with some confusion( 疑惑 ), of her love for Mr. Darcy.

article_info.previous: Elizabeth终于等到和Mr. Darcy单独在一起的机会，鼓起勇气向他表示了感谢。Darcy大胆承认自己这样做是想让Elizabeth开心并且承认自己对于她的爱恋从来都没有改变过。Elizabeth欣然接受了Darcy的示爱并且也袒露了自己的感情。两位有情人磕磕碰碰终于冰释前嫌走到了一起。
article_info.share_words: The acknowledged lovers talked and laughed, while the unacknowledged were silent.

question.cn: 关于Jane和Mr. Bingley的订婚，Mr. Darcy的反应是什么？
question.en: What was Mr. Darcy's reaction towards the engagement between Jane and Mr. Bingley?

analysis: 文中对话中提到：“Darcy was very pleased that his friend was now engaged to Jane.” 所以选A。

question.cn: 关于自己和Darcy的订婚，Elizabeth最担心的是什么？
question.en: What was Elizabeth's biggest worry about her upcoming engagement with Darcy?

options.cn: 她非常担心婚礼的费用。
options.en: She was concerned about the money the wedding may cost.

options.cn: 她非常忧虑家人们的反应因为他们都不太喜欢Darcy。
options.en: She was concerned about her family's reaction since they didn't like Darcy.
She was worried about Lady's Catherine's objection.

analysis: 文中提到：“She wondered about how the family would react when they found out about her situation, because she knew that no one liked Darcy except Jane.”可知选择B。

question.cn: 在知道了Elizabeth和Darcy即将订婚的消息后，Mr. Bennet的反应是怎样的？
question.en: How did Mr. Bennet feel after hearing the new about Elizabeth's possible engagement?

options.cn: 他不太相信并且很不安。
options.en: He doubted about it and was very anxious.

analysis: 文中提到：“ Her father was walking around the room, looking serious and anxious.”并且后来Mr. Bennet询问了Elizabeth可知选择C。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第99天
